title: 'Roos prepare for season as cloud lingers over assistant coach M
text:
KANSAS CITY, MO (KCTV) - A UMKC assistant basketball assistant remains on administrative leave as more calls come for his former boss, Rick Pitino, to resign.
The UMKC basketball team practiced Wednesday morning, and reporters were instructed not to ask any questions about Andre McGee.
While working at the University of Louisville, McGee is accused of hiring escorts and other dancers to strip and have sex with former recruits and players. McGee left the University of Louisville in 2014 to join the UMKC staff.
McGee also played for Pitino, who has denied any knowledge of the sex parties.
"I don't know if any of this is true or not," Pitino told ESPN's Dana O'Neil by phone Tuesday. "There's only one person who knows the truth, and he needs to come out and tell the truth to his teammates, to the University of Louisville, to his fans and to his coaches that have taught him to do the right thing for years and allowed him to be part of something special here.
"He's the only one with any answers. Whether it's true or not, I don't know. ... Everything else is absurd. I don't care about the legal issues. If he's done something wrong, he has to own up to it and do his penance."
McGee has been silent, but his attorney, Scott Cox, has slammed the book making the allegations.
"I can tell you that all the evidence we've looked at supports his version of events, which is that he never paid her or anyone else to have sex with a player or a recruit," Cox said.
Cox's comments came as one of the escorts detailed her conversations with McGee about negotiating prices for escorts and the type of girl that a recruit wanted.
The escort said McGee told her that Pitino was aware of the sex parties.
"To say I'm disheartened and disappointed would be probably the biggest understatement I've made since I've been a coach," Pitino said.
UMKC basketball coach Kareem Richardson, who was an assistant coach on Louisville's national championship team in 2013, said his team is focused on the upcoming season.
"The ultimate goal is to win a championship, the regular season first and foremost and then hopefully to win a conference championship," Richardson said.
